page.title: 04Landscape of the Downs
page.content: The most striking feature of the Downs is that there are extremely few plants above six feet in height. This is due to both the high winds and the thin layer of soil above the underlying chalk. As trees need firm, deep roots if they are to grow high, the six to twelve inches of topsoil does not suffice - especially in the strong winds that occur on the unprotected slopes above the cliffs. As a result of these conditions, a large proportion of the ground is bare and, where it is covered, the scrub is very low. This has the effect of enabling one to see far over the Downs in each direction. The Downs themselves are smooth and there are no steep slopes apart from the cliffs. Their height is between 400 & 500 feet - no further building is allowed above 300 feet.
